newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: SAB announces $360 mln share offer.
newsitem.headline: SAB announces $360 mln share offer.

text.p: South African Breweries Ltd announced on Friday that it had authorised an offering of around $360 million to fund its international expansion.

It said the issue would take the form of 20 South African cents each and American Depositary Shares (each representing the right to receive an ordinary share) at a price of $25.43 (115 rand) per share, aggregating to 14.25 million new South African Breweries (SAB) shares of 20 South African cents each.
The offer could be raised to $410 million if there was sufficient demand via an over-allocation option.
The company said international demand for its share offering had exceeded $600 million.
The issue price represented a discount of about four percent to the share's closing price of 120 rand on October 3.
The offering is one of the largest emerging market equity issues to international investors undertaken by a private sector company, it said.
The proceeds would be used, subject to the approval of South African exchange control authorities, to fund the company's continuing expansion of its interests outside South Africa.

"In connection with the offering, Robert Fleming & Co Ltd, on behalf of the managers to the issue, may over-allot or effect transactions which stabilise or maintain the market price of the securities at levels which might not otherwise prevail," the company said.
Such stabilising, if commenced, could be discontinued at any time.
Subject to final approval from the Johannesburg and London Stock Exchanges, the new South African Breweries shares would be listed on both exchanges from October 10.

If the proceeds of the offering had been available to the company at the financial year ended March 31, assuming the exercise in full of the over-allocation option, there would have been no material impact on earnings per share.
"However, net asset value per share would have increased from 1,881 South African cents to approximately 2,400 South African cents," it said.
